ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Online lecture and seminar combination with lots of individual interaction to practice performance and other music skills
In addition to live virtual lectures with the entire class, we had individual live virtual check-ins to evaluate our preparedness and progress in the course.

Every other week, we also had one-on-one check-ins  with Professor Tai. During these 5-10 min sessions, we would do a sight-singing and rhythm exercise exercise and go over any questions we had about topics in class.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I learned a lot about chords and chord notation, terms for the structure of music, and gained a lot of practice reading/performing music. 

Learning terms for certain patterns in music (like the names of non harmonic tones, cadences, periods/sentences, etc) helped me better understand them and their role in music, as well as better communicate musical knowledge in general.

I think practice performing rhythms and singing was really useful in helping me gain confidence as a musician. I could have benefitted from some more sight singing since that was most difficult, but I really appreciate the singing skills I gained just by practicing. I think singing helps a musician tremendously, even if instrumentalists never actually have to sing. 

If I had to pick one thing I learned that I appreciate the most, its definitely bass figures/chord notation because I find myself understanding the structure of music and different notations of music so much better.
I learned a lot of basic sight singing skills and got a lot of practice with rhythm and reading without practice.
I sharpened my aural music theory skills.

I improved my sight-singing and rhythm abilities. Everyone had to sing something solo or clap a rhythm at least once every class, so along with regular homework, we benefit from consistent practice with feedback (eg being aware of jumps in intervals, aiming for more legato). 

We also learned about Western chord progressions, starting from recognizing intervals between two notes and building up to identifying the chords and writing two-part phrases. However, I would garner this was not as rigorous as MUSI 210 might be in terms of learning how to be as perfect as possible at following composition 'rules.' For me, though, taking a less technically demanding class like 218 was my goal.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The instructor was very nice, approachable, and willing to provide extra help if needed. The workload was low but I still feel like I learned a lot so it was a very enjoyable half credit class. It was probably my least stressful and most fun course this semester because the instructor was so nice and it was so interesting to learn more about music theory while also putting it to practical use. There is a good balance of new concepts with plenty of practice to reinforce the skills we learn. This course also created a better sense of community than many other classes, perhaps due to the small size and collaborative nature of the course. Given that I didn't get to know any of my classmates in my other classes, I'd say this course did a good job of making me feel like I had classmates! 

Weaknesses: As with any online course, it's still hard to really connect with other people in the class. There were also some concepts we learned that were rarely put to practical use in the course. For example, we learned about suspensions and non harmonic tones but rarely used this knowledge when analyzing excerpts. I also felt I didn't learn as much about resolutions in music as I could have with some more focus on it in class and more applications of this knowledge when analyzing excerpts.

Strengths: good amount of work

Weaknesses: More clear methodology for learning skills.

Strengths: The professor was very engaging and kind. There was a lot of time to submit homework assignments. The assignments were exactly what we were tested on, so I always felt very prepared. The class is repetitive, but in the end, you will be much better at aural music theory than when you started. 

Weaknesses: The class is fast-paced, so if you are unfamiliar with sightreading or with aural training, you may be lost.

Strengths: very reasonable workload, exercises structured so everyone will always participate at least a few times in class, nice feedback, generally chill class with Professor Tai. I enjoyed whenever we had collaborative exercises, like writing out a chord progression, and wish we a) got more time to do those in class, and b) got more similar activities outside of class so we could get to know our classmates better.

Weaknesses: not many, one of them would be that my class was TTh at 8:15 AM EST, which is probably one of the earliest times possible!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Asking students to take turns performing in class was very helpful for learning and getting to know classmates. 

The instructor was also extremely accessible outside of class and very willing to help.

Taking it virtually decreased the value of the aural training, which is usually done in live, timed environments; however, it being virtual eliminated the stress of identifying chords/melodies after one playing.

Sometimes Zoom will cut audio off, especially if it's not a voice. During rhythm clapping exercises, people's clapping would be silenced by Zoom, so we would have to hold our hands up to the camera to show the claps visually. Not a huge problem, but if some small mistake was made we would probably just move on and attribute the mistake to Zoom. Maybe double checking that everyone's audio settings are ideal for music?

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This course was very fun and I learned a lot. I met a lot of other great musicians at Yale and the instructor was very kind and approachable. I was rarely stressed about this class but I find myself applying the knowledge and skills I gained in my daily life as a musician, although I'm not a music major!
Yes! This course is a stress-free way to improve your aural music training.

If you're taking private lessons and aren't looking at this point in time to dive deep into complicated and more time-consuming music theory, this class on musicianship is the way to go. Additionally, if you're looking to learn how to do basic sight-singing like any good musician should, this class is very good at teaching how to sight-sing.
